title: Citi and Junior Achievement Launch the 'Be Entrepreneurial' Education Program in Romania
summary: Bucharest, Romania - In times of economic crises, when new business models emerge, particularly those leading to cost reductions, it becomes even clearer that entrepreneurship is important for economic growth, productivity, innovation and employment. Citi Romania and Junior Achievement have partnered to launch a new in-school educational program called 'Be Entrepreneurial,' supported by a US$50,000 grant from the Citi Foundation. The program is aimed at promoting entrepreneurial thinking among 4,500 students aged 15-17 from high schools across the country and to encourage them to consider starting up a business later on.
tag-1: Citi and Junior Achievement Launch the 'Be Entrepreneurial' Education Program in Romania
tag-3: Bucharest, Romania – In times of economic crises, when new business models emerge, particularly those leading to cost reductions, it becomes even clearer that entrepreneurship is important for economic growth, productivity, innovation and employment. Citi Romania and Junior Achievement have partnered to launch a new in-school educational program called 'Be Entrepreneurial,' supported by a US$50,000 grant from the Citi Foundation. The program is aimed at promoting entrepreneurial thinking among 4,500 students aged 15-17 from high schools across the country and to encourage them to consider starting up a business later on.
tag-4: With the support of teachers and Citibank volunteers, the program will give students throughout the country an opportunity to better understand how an enterprise works, to the gain basic skills to run a small business at the end of high school and to fit better in an economy driven by the triple bottom-line approach, a framework that incorporates three dimensions of performance: economic, environmental and social.
tag-5: The program also includes a national business plan competition to stimulate students' competitiveness and competencies. Students who successfully complete the program will be able to take the Enterprise Driving License national assessment, developed by Junior Achievement Romania in partnership with the Ministry of Education.
tag-6: "As globalization reshapes the international economic landscape and technological change creates greater demands to be met in the world economy, entrepreneurship is believed to offer ways to help rise up to new economic, social and environmental challenges. Through this partnership with Junior Achievement, we seek to provide students in Romania with the knowledge, skills and motivation to encourage their entrepreneurial aspirations," said Tibor Pandi, Citi Country Officer for Romania.
tag-7: "It is a general strategy of all education systems to develop in schools, as early possible, innovation, creativity and enterprise spirit. 'Be Entrepreneurial' is preparing high school students for independent life and good careers. With such programs, the business community is a reliable partner and Citi a great investor and role model. I'm sure we will be seeing positive results soon," said ?tefania E. Popp, Executive Director of Junior Achievement Romania.
tag-8: All students and teachers enrolled in the program will receive the 'Be Entrepreneurial' tool kit, consisting of a Student Manual, Teacher & Business Volunteer Guide and other additional materials. The activities will be facilitated by Citibank volunteers, who will work with the students throughout the school year to help them develop an entrepreneurial spirit.

tag-14: Junior Achievement Since 1993, Junior Achievement Romania implements programs for students of all levels under the slogan "Invest in education!" Junior Achievement Romania is part of Junior Achievement Worldwide, USA and JA-YE, Europe. Our mission is to inspire and prepare the young generation to succeed in a market economy. In Romania, the JA "learning by doing" programs are followed annually by 150.000 students from 1.000 schools with the support of 2.500 teachers and implemented locally in partnership with the Romanian Ministry of Education, Research, Youth and Sports and the business community.
